real.content:
It wasn’t my intention to work for a multinational telco, I was happy working for a successful, family owned reseller in the IP Telephony and Contact Centre environment, but when Vodafone bought Central Telecom in late 2008, I learnt very quickly that working for one the UK’s largest communication organisations was exactly where I should be.
I graduated from the University of Derby with a degree in Business Studies. I was clear right from the get-go that I wanted to work in marketing and I was fortunate enough to secure a role at Central Telecom, a reasonably sized and successful privately owned business working as a Marketing Assistant. Why Marketing? It suited my skills - combining creativity and innovation with insight and analytics. Why Central Telecom? It was a fast growing, agile reseller organisation. It had aspirations to be the communication partner of choice for national private and public sector organisations providing fixed solutions (IPT, Calls and lines, contact centres) working alongside Avaya, Mitel and Nortel. I wanted to gain as much experience as possible across the entirety of the marketing mix and I wanted to work for an organisation in the techsector, that was punching above its weight and winning. After 9 great years of moving through the organisation gaining demand generation, event, and online experience I became Head of Marketing for the company and it was soon after this that Vodafone bought Central Telecom.
For Vodafone UK this was one of the first initial steps towards convergence.
For me…I had a choice, choose to stay in the Midlands and look for a local opportunity or take up the cultural challenge of going from working for a family business to one of the world’s largest mobile operators. The decision was easy and I’ve not looked back. Working for Vodafone continues to broaden my experience and has offers me unlimited opportunities. I’ve worked as a UC Marketing Manager as we began our journey to convergence, in around 2009. I’ve led our demand generation marketing activity for our mid-market teams and developed vertical market stories for Retail, Finance and Legal and just over 12 months ago I became the Senior Marketing Lead for the Partners and Alliances function of Enterprise – bringing my experience of working for an indirect partner, my convergence background, relationship with alliance organisations and my nearly 9 years of experience at Vodafone neatly into a role that I believe was made for me. I love the fact that nothing at Vodafone stays the same for too long, that we work in a fast paced industry and that there are so many opportunities. I’m loving the challenge of winning the hearts and minds of our partner community and the personal challenge of becoming a digital marketer. At Vodafone we do make difference, what we do matters and I’m proud to play my part. Based on the passage above, How did the author's skills and interests align with their desire to work in marketing for Central Telecom?

The author's skills and interests aligned with their desire to work in marketing for Central Telecom because marketing suited their creativity and innovation skills while also incorporating insight and analytics. Additionally, they wanted to work for an agile reseller organization that was punching above its weight and winning in the tech sector. The author also wanted to gain as much experience as possible across the entirety of the marketing mix.

What were some of the military STEM activities that the G-FORCE team participated in, and what was their role?
Generate according to: While working towards my Congressional Award Gold Medal, I dedicated 385 hours as the head programmer, lead robot driver, and co-captain of the 4-H robotics team G-FORCE. My team works out of Accident, MD, but we also participate in numerous Community Outreach events globally.
SuGO, a game with sumo wrestling robots, is one of the most popular STEM activities and the reason I became interested in STEM. Utilizing SuGO, virtual reality, rockets, WeDO, and many other STEM activities, I volunteered at the West Virginia Children’s Hospital, Maryland State Fair, Mineral State Stem Festival, and 4-H Volunteer Forum.
I have had the opportunity to be the referee and robot and field inspector at FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) Qualifiers and State Championships in three different states. All of these activities are free STEM activities available to the public.
The most memorable STEM events were the military activities, the largest of which was the Air Force STEM initiative. Team G-FORCE was given a budget of $250,000 to buy, package, and ship STEM products to over 52 Air Force bases. We live streamed webinars taught by the team members on how to use the STEM kits. The team also hosted two one-week residential Navy STEM camps where forty 4-Hers from bases abroad (Japan, Bahrain, and Italy) and domestic (Georgia) were taught lessons on hardware and software by me and my fellow mentors.
I traveled to Washington, D.C. For the USA Science & Engineering Festival where I volunteered at three booths: FIRST, 4-H, and Maker Space. While there, I demonstrated the robotics competition, lead the Junk Drawer Robotics, and ran the software that cut vinyl stickers, adding additional creativity to the patrons’ work.
Following this year’s festival, I joined my 4-H robotics coach in a special project where we learned a new programming language together. We were tasked by the Oakland Lions Club to create a belt sander race for their jubilee that they could use for years.
Last year my FIRST Tech Challenge team had a very intuitive program for our robot. It was able to make decisions about which claw to open and close and how high to raise its arm, based on simple choices made by me and my co-pilot. This year we plan to make the robot even smarter. As head programmer, I have already moved on from using pre-programmed vision software, to creating a custom image processing pipeline.
Learn more about The Congressional Award STEM Stars program.

The G-FORCE team participated in several military STEM activities, including the Air Force STEM initiative. They were given a budget of $250,000 to buy, package, and ship STEM products to over 52 Air Force bases. The team also hosted two one-week residential Navy STEM camps where they taught lessons on hardware and software to forty 4-Hers from bases abroad and domestic locations. As the head programmer and co-captain of the team, the student was responsible for teaching lessons and leading the camps. Additionally, the team volunteered at several military STEM events, including FIRST Tech Challenge Qualifiers and State Championships in three different states.

real.content: How do CGI and animatronics work together in creating special effects in film?

CGI (Computer Generated Imagery) and animatronics are two different techniques used in creating special effects in films. 

CGI involves using computer software to generate realistic 3D models, digital backgrounds, and special effects. The software is capable of creating realistic characters and environments that exist only in the digital world. 

Meanwhile, animatronics involves using mechanical devices to create lifelike robots or creatures with moving parts. This is typically achieved by using motors and control systems that allow the animatronic to move its limbs, head, and other body parts in a natural-looking way.

In film production, CGI and animatronics are often used together to create realistic and seamless special effects. For example, filmmakers may use animatronics to create the physical body of a monster, while using CGI to add texture and details like skin and fur. Meanwhile, the use of CGI can enhance the movements of the animatronic, making it even more believable.

Overall, both techniques have their strengths and limitations, but when used together, can create truly stunning and convincing special effects in films.

7. In summary, CGI and animatronics are complementary tools that can be used together to produce highly effective and engaging special effects in films. They complement each other's strengths and provide filmmakers with new ways to bring their visions to life.

real.content: Write a comprehensive report that compares renewable energy sources such as wind, solar, hydro, geothermal, and biomass, analyzing their costs, benefits, and drawbacks in terms of economic feasibility. Provide statistical and empirical evidence to support your arguments, and assess the potential impact of governmental policies, market forces, and technological advancements on the adoption and diffusion of these energy sources. Introduction

As the world struggles to address climate change and reduce carbon emissions, renewable energy sources have become increasingly vital. In this report, I will compare renewable energy sources such as wind, solar, hydro, geothermal, and biomass in terms of economic feasibility, costs, benefits, and drawbacks. I will provide statistical and empirical evidence to support my arguments and assess the potential impact of governmental policies, market forces, and technological advancements on the adoption and diffusion of these sources.

Literature Review

Renewable energy sources have become increasingly popular over the years due to their cost-effectiveness and low carbon emissions. Wind power has become one of the most widely adopted renewable energy sources, and its growth rate has been steady. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), wind power has the potential to generate up to 70% of global electricity by 2050 (IEA, 2020). The costs of wind power have significantly decreased over the past decade, making it one of the most affordable sources of electricity.

Solar power is another popular renewable energy type, and it is growing rapidly. Solar panels have become cheaper over the past years, and their efficiency has been improving. Currently, solar power is responsible for approximately 2% of global energy production, but the IEA predicts that it could potentially generate up to 35% of global electricity by 2050 (IEA, 2020).

Hydroelectric power has been used for centuries, and it remains one of the most prevalent sources of renewable energy in the world. Hydroelectricity is highly feasible since it provides reliable electricity and has low operational costs. However, it requires large-scale infrastructure investment, and its environmental impact needs to be considered.

Geothermal energy is a highly sustainable and reliable source of electricity, and it is abundant in some areas of the world. It provides a stable electricity source, and its carbon emissions are significantly low. However, the high upfront costs required for setting up geothermal power plants make it relatively expensive compared to other renewable energy sources.

Biomass energy is produced by decomposing organic matter. It is a versatile and flexible resource that can easily be converted into electricity. However, its adoption as a reliable source of energy has been hindered due to issues regarding its sustainability and carbon emissions.

Methodology

To evaluate the economic feasibility of renewable energy sources, I relied on a comparative analysis of the costs, benefits, and drawbacks of each energy source. I used statistical and empirical data from credible sources such as the IEA, the US Energy Information Administration, and academic publications on renewable energy. I compared the potential impact of governmental policies, market forces, and technological advancements on the adoption and diffusion of these energy sources.

Findings

Wind Energy
Wind energy is one of the most affordable renewable energy sources, and its costs have steeply declined over the years. Its levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) in 2020 was approximately $44 per megawatt-hour (MWh). Wind energy is highly feasible since it is an abundant resource worldwide, and it can be deployed in almost any location. However, wind turbines can have negative environmental impacts, such as bird strikes and noise pollution, and require ample space to set them up.

Solar Energy
The cost of solar energy has drastically declined over the past decade, making it one of the most affordable sources of renewable energy. According to IEA, the levelized cost of solar photovoltaics (PV) fell by 87% between 2010 and 2020. The LCOE of solar energy in 2020 was approximately $63 per MWh. Solar energy is highly feasible since it can be deployed almost anywhere with access to sunlight, and it has no carbon emissions. However, solar panels require a significant amount of space, and their efficiency can be affected by factors such as weather and pollution.

Hydroelectric Power
Hydroelectric power is relatively affordable and highly reliable. Its LCOE in 2020 was approximately $70 per MWh, making it one of the most cost-effective renewable energy sources. However, it requires a significant upfront cost to set up, and its environmental impact needs to be carefully considered.

Geothermal Energy
Geothermal power is highly sustainable and reliable, and its LCOE in 2020 was approximately $68 per MWh. However, it requires significant upfront investment, and its deployment is restricted to areas where geothermal heat is available.

Biomass Energy
Biomass energy is highly versatile and flexible, and it can easily be converted into electricity. Its LCOE in 2020 was approximately $100 per MWh, making it relatively expensive compared to other renewable energy sources. Biomass energy raises concerns about sustainability and carbon emissions, and its environmental impact needs to be carefully considered.

Discussion

In many countries, governments have implemented policies such as feed-in tariffs, tax credits, and renewable portfolio standards to incentivize the adoption of renewable energy sources. real.content: Write a step-by-step guide detailing the process of creating a rustic dining table from scratch using reclaimed wood and basic woodworking tools.

Step 1: Gather Materials and Tools
Start by gathering materials such as reclaimed wood, sandpaper, saws, a drill, screws, wood glue, table legs, and a measuring tape. You may also need clamps, a straight edge, and a level.

Step 2: Plan the Design
Sketch out a design for your table, taking into consideration the size, shape, and style that you want. Calculate the dimensions for the table and create a list of the required components.

Step 3: Prepare the Wood
Clear and prepare the wood by sanding it with rough-grit sandpaper. You may need to remove nails, screws, or staples that are lodged in the wood.

Step 4: Cut and Shape the Wood
Use a saw to cut the wood pieces according to your design. You should create the top, apron, and legs of the table. Use a straight edge or level to ensure that your cuts are straight and even.

Step 5: Sand the Pieces
Use medium-grit sandpaper to smooth out the rough cut edges of the wood pieces. Then use fine-grit sandpaper to create a smooth and polished finish.

Step 6: Assemble the Table Top
Use wood glue to attach the tabletop boards together carefully. After that, clamp the pieces together tightly for a few hours until the glue has completely dried out.

Step 7: Attach the Table Apron
Attach the apron to the tabletop. You can use screws and wood glue for a strong bond. Make sure that the apron is flush with the tabletop.

Step 8: Attach the Legs
Attach the legs to the tabletop and apron. Ensure that the legs are straight and in the right position before securing them with screws and wood glue.

Step 9: Sand the Entire Table
Using fine-grit sandpaper, sand the entire table, including the legs and apron. Ensure that the surface is smooth and polished.

Step 10: Apply Finish
Choose a finish that best fits your style and apply it to the table. Use a brush or rag to apply the finish evenly. Allow the finish to dry completely before using the table.

Congratulations, you now have a rustic dining table made from reclaimed wood! Enjoy it with family and friends.

Step 1: Develop a feedback form
Create a simple and easy-to-use feedback form that can be accessed by customers through multiple platforms, including email, social media, website, and phone. Ensure that the form includes essential fields, such as name, email address, phone number, and comment box, and provide clear instructions.

Step 2: Provide incentives
Offer incentives such as discount coupons, freebies, or loyalty points to encourage customers to provide feedback. Ensure that the incentives are relevant to the product/service, and the feedback is genuine.

Step 3: Set up a customer support team
Create a dedicated team that will be responsible for responding to customer inquiries and concerns. They should have excellent communication skills, be knowledgeable about your products/services, and have access to the necessary information to provide timely and effective responses to customer inquiries and concerns.

Step 4: Implement a tracking system
Use a tracking system to monitor customer feedback and track response times. This will ensure that all feedback is addressed in a timely manner, and you can analyze patterns and trends in customer feedback to identify areas for improvement.

Step 5: Be transparent and responsive
Be transparent and responsive to customer feedback. Respond to all inquiries and concerns promptly, and provide updates as necessary. Use the feedback to improve your products/services, and communicate how you are addressing customer feedback to demonstrate your commitment to customer satisfaction.

Step 6: Analyze feedback and take action
Analyze customer feedback regularly to identify common issues and areas for improvement. Use this information to make necessary changes to your products/services and improve the overall customer experience.

Step 7: Communicate with customers
Communicate regularly with customers through newsletters, social media, and other communication channels to keep them informed about company updates, new products/services, and improvements resulting from customer feedback.

By setting up a comprehensive customer feedback system, you can encourage customer feedback, respond to inquiries and concerns promptly, and improve the overall customer experience.

real.content: What are the adaptations of camels that allow them to thrive in their desert habitat?

Camels have several adaptations that allow them to thrive in their desert habitat:

1. Humps: Camels have two humps on their backs that store fat, which they can use for energy when food and water are scarce.

2. Long eyelashes and nostrils: Camels have long eyelashes and nostrils that can be closed to protect them from sandstorms.

3. Thick fur: Camels have a thick fur coat that helps them regulate their body temperature, keeping them warm in cold desert nights and cool during the hot day.

4. Large feet: Camels have large, wide feet that help them walk on sand without sinking.

5. Efficient water use: Camels can survive for long periods without water as they can drink up to 135 liters of water at one time and store it in their stomachs.

6. Ability to tolerate high temperatures: Camels can tolerate temperatures up to 50°C, without sweating because their body temperature is a bit higher than most mammals. 

These adaptations allow camels to survive and thrive in their harsh desert habitat.

real.content: How does video conferencing accommodate for language barriers?

Video conferencing can accommodate for language barriers in various ways:

1. Real-time language translation - Some video conferencing software like Zoom and Microsoft Teams offer real-time language translation features that automatically translate speech between multiple languages in real-time. This can help participants who speak different languages understand each other better.

2. Closed captions or subtitles - Some video conferencing software also provide closed caption or subtitle options which allow participants to read a transcript of the conversation in their own language while the conversation is going on. This is particularly useful for individuals with hearing impairments and for those who have difficulty understanding the spoken language.

3. Pre-translated documents - It's also possible to use pre-translated documents such as agendas, reports, and presentations to ensure that everyone can access and understand specific information.

4. Human language interpretation services - Participants can also hire a professional interpreter to provide simultaneous interpreting for the conference, whether in-person or through video conferencing software designed specifically for interpreting.

Overall, video conferencing technology can offer a variety of solutions to accommodate for language barriers, allowing individuals who speak different languages to communicate in real-time, exchange information, and collaborate effectively.

Title: Drama on the Stage

Characters:
1. Olivia - lead actress of the musical
2. Ethan - lead actor of the musical
3. Chloe - Olivia's best friend and supporting actress
4. Tyler - Ethan's best friend and supporting actor
5. Ms. Sanders - the musical director

Act 1:
Scene 1:
Olivia, Chloe, Ethan, and Tyler enter the stage. The cast is rehearsing the opening number. Chloe and Tyler are practicing their dance moves while Olivia and Ethan are setting up the props. 

Olivia: (sarcastically) This musical is going to be a disaster. 

Ethan: Why do you say that?

Olivia: Look at Tyler and Chloe, they are still struggling with the dance moves.

Chloe: (defensive) We'll get it right! 

Ms. Sanders enters.

Ms. Sanders: (authoritative) Alright, everyone. Let's get back to work. 

Scene 2:
Olivia and Ethan are practicing their duet, and Chloe and Tyler are practicing their dance routine on the other side of the stage.

Chloe: (whispers to Tyler) Don't you think Ethan and Olivia are getting a little too close?

Tyler: (whispers back) (Laughs) Yeah! They are practically eating each other's faces!

Suddenly, Ethan stumbles and falls into Olivia. They both fall onto the ground.

Olivia: (teasingly) Ethan, are you trying to get closer to me?

Ethan: (smiling) No, I just wanted to check if your acting skills were realistic enough. 

Ms. Sanders: (pleadingly) Can we please keep our focus on the musical? We only have a week before the show.

Act 2:
Scene 1:
Chloe and Tyler are practicing their duet. Tyler gets too close to Chloe, which makes her uncomfortable.

Chloe: (annoyed) Tyler, can you please back off?

Tyler: (jomokingly) I can't help it if I'm drawn to your charm. 

Chloe: (sarcastically) Yeah, right. Just keep your distance.

Scene 2:
Ethan and Olivia are practicing their love scene when Olivia kisses Ethan for real.

Ethan: (surprised) What was that for?

Olivia: (happily) Sorry, it's just that I've had a crush on you for so long.

Ethan: (blushing) Really? I had no idea.

The two kiss again.

Chloe enters.

Chloe: (surprised) What's going on here?

Olivia: (embarrassed) Ummm, we were just rehearsing.

Chloe: (sarcastically) Oh, I can see that.

Scene 3:
It's opening night of the musical. The stage is decorated with colorful lights and props. The audience is applauding as the curtain rises.

Olivia and Ethan sing their duet. Chloe and Tyler join in, performing their dance moves flawlessly. The audience is mesmerized.

Ms. Sanders is backstage, pleased with how smoothly the show is going. Suddenly, she hears a loud crash. She runs onstage to find one of the props has fallen and hit Ethan on the head.

Ms. Sanders: (panicked) Is anyone a doctor?

Chloe: (concerned) Is he going to be okay?

Ms. Sanders: (trying to remain calm) I hope so. We need to take him to the hospital.

real.content: What is the history of the Bauhaus movement in art and design?

The Bauhaus movement originated in Germany during the early 20th century. It was founded in 1919 by Walter Gropius, a renowned architect who sought to unite fine arts and applied arts under one roof. The goal of the movement was to create a new kind of art that could be used to design functional objects for everyday use.

The Bauhaus school combined traditional craftsmanship and modern technology to create simple, functional designs. It was influenced by both the Arts and Crafts Movement and the De Stijl movement. The school attracted many talented artists, architects, and designers, including Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky, and Marcel Breuer.

The Bauhaus movement emphasized simplicity and functionality in design, with an emphasis on the use of geometric shapes and primary colors. It was also known for its emphasis on mass production and standardization, which made it possible to create affordable designs for the masses.

The Bauhaus school was closed in 1933 due to pressure from the Nazi regime, but its influence continued to be felt throughout the world. Many of its artists and designers emigrated to other countries, including the United States, where they continued to champion the ideals of the Bauhaus movement.

Today, the influence of the Bauhaus movement can be seen in many areas of design, from furniture to fashion to architecture. Its legacy continues to inspire new generations of artists and designers, who seek to create functional, beautiful designs that are accessible to all.

real.content: What are the most promising renewable energy sources for large-scale energy production?

The most promising renewable energy sources for large-scale energy production are:

1. Solar Energy - Solar power is the conversion of energy from sunlight into electricity or heat. It is the fastest-growing renewable energy source worldwide and has the potential to produce significant amounts of energy with the right infrastructure.

2. Wind Energy - Wind energy is the conversion of energy from the wind into electricity through the use of wind turbines. It is a well-established technology and has the potential to be a major source of electricity in the future.

3. Hydro Power - Hydro power is the conversion of energy from moving water into electricity. It is a proven technology that can produce a large amount of electricity, especially in areas with large bodies of water.

4. Geothermal Energy - Geothermal energy is the heat from the earth, which can be harnessed to generate electricity. It is a reliable source of energy that can be used 24/7, and it has the potential to produce significant amounts of energy.

5. Biomass Energy - Biomass energy is the conversion of organic material (like wood, crops, or waste) into energy. It is a renewable source of energy and can be used to generate electricity, heat, or fuel for vehicles.

The play should focus on a protagonist who overcomes major obstacles through determination and grit. The genre should be drama, with moments of humor sprinkled in. The play should include no more than 5 main characters, with at least 2 of them representing obstacles that the protagonist must overcome. The script should include stage directions and descriptions of sets and costumes. The play should be no longer than 90 minutes, and should have a clear and satisfying resolution showcasing the power of perseverance.

ACT I

Scene 1
The play opens with the protagonist, JASON, a high school student, staring at his college application form with a somber expression. He’s surrounded by his friends, JESSICA and TREVOR, who have already been accepted into their dream colleges. 

Jessica: What’s wrong, Jason? 

Jason: I’m thinking of ending my dream of going to college, guys. I’m not that bright, and my family can’t afford it. 

Trevor: That’s not true, bro. Perseverance is the key to success, you know that.

Scene 2
The stage transforms into the school talent show. Jason and his friends are backstage. Jason is holding a guitar, looking at his fingers nervously as though he’s never played before. 

Jessica: (Whispering) It’s showtime, Jason! Remember, you got this! 

The curtain goes up, and the spotlight shines on Jason. He starts playing his guitar, and Jess and Trev are dancing to the rhythm. But during the final guitar solo, Jason’s fingers slip, and he hits the wrong note. Everyone in the audience laughs. 

Scene 3
The next day at school. Jason is sitting alone, with his head on his desk. His music teacher, MR. ROBERTS, walks in.

Mr. Roberts: Hey, Jason, listen to me. Life is full of ups and downs. You can’t give up because you made a mistake. The most successful people have all had failures. What makes them different is that they keep trying until they get it right. 

ACT II

Scene 1
The stage transforms into a basketball court. Jason is practicing dribbling on his own. Suddenly, two players from the opposing team, RICK and KEVIN, walk up to Jason and start heckling him. 

Rick: What are you even doing here, loser? You can’t even dribble a ball.

Kevin: Yeah, go back to your guitar, man.

Scene 2 
Jason walks home, visibly upset. He enters his room and sits alone, staring at his guitar. His father walks in.

Father: (Sighs) What’s wrong with you, son? 

Jason: I just can’t seem to get anything right, dad. Music or basketball, I’m a failure.  

Father: (Sits down) Life doesn’t work that way, son. You can’t be good at everything. You have to keep trying until you find out what you’re good at. 

Scene 3
The stage transitions into a library. Jason is studying hard, with books piled up around him, his head buried in one of them. His friends Jess and Trev come in.

Jess: Jason, did you hear? The college you applied to sent you an acceptance letter!

Jason: (Jumps up) Wow, really?

Trev: Yeah, dude, you’re going to college! 

ACT III

Scene 1
The stage transforms into a college classroom. Jason is sitting there, looking at the unfamiliar faces around him. The professor walks in.

Professor: Good morning, class. As you all know, the course is rigorous, and the curriculum is demanding. You will need to persevere to succeed. 

Scene 2
The stage shifts to a basketball court. Jason is now on the college basketball team. He’s dribbling, and his team members are cheering him on. He tosses the ball through the hoop, and the buzzer goes off. The game is won!

Scene 3
The stage transforms into a music room. Jason is singing, and his friends Jess and Trev are clapping. Jason looks confident and happy.

THE END.

The person who inspires me the most is my grandmother, Maria. She is a beacon of strength, resilience, and compassion, and has positively impacted my life in countless ways.

I first realized the depth of her influence on me when I moved away from home for college. As I navigated the challenges of newfound independence and academic rigor, I often turned to her for guidance and support. Despite the physical distance between us, she has remained a constant presence in my life, always willing to lend an ear or offer words of encouragement.

One of the things I admire most about my grandmother is her unwavering determination. She grew up in poverty in rural Mexico, and faced numerous obstacles as a young woman trying to build a better life for herself and her family. But through sheer grit and perseverance, she was able to establish a successful business and provide for her loved ones. Witnessing her tenacity in the face of adversity has taught me the value of hard work and perseverance, and has inspired me to pursue my own goals with similar determination.

My grandmother's kindness and generosity are also qualities that I strive to emulate. Despite her own struggles, she never hesitates to offer a helping hand to those in need, whether it be a plate of food or a kind word. Her selflessness and compassion have taught me to prioritize the needs of others, and to always seek out opportunities to lend a helping hand.

On a more personal level, my grandmother has always been a source of strength and comfort during difficult times. When I lost a close family member a few years ago, she was the one who held me while I cried, and reminded me of the love and support of our community. Her unwavering support and empathy in times of hardship have helped me develop my own emotional resilience, and have taught me the importance of seeking solace in loved ones during tough times.

In many ways, my grandmother has been a role model not only for me, but for our entire family. Her unwavering dedication to her loved ones, her fierce independence, and her boundless empathy have left an indelible mark on all of us. As I continue to grow and pursue my own dreams, I carry her example with me, always striving to embody the same strength, compassion, and resolve that she has shown throughout her life.

real.content:
A trip to Iceland had always been part of our wish list, even more of a focus when many of the migrants which pass through Skye are Iceland bound. Our 9 day trip was all too short as this is a big country with a great deal to see, and we concentrated our efforts in the north. Breeding densities of waders was amazing and Whimbrel, Redshank, Golden Plover and Black-tailed Godwit were everywhere and breeding productivity was high. There are few natural predators, and an absence of domestic cats and Hooded Crows no doubt contributes to this. On Flatey Island, Red-necked Phalaropes were running around at our feet and our only disappointment was that the brilliant breeding plumage of Grey Phalaropes evaded us. A Gyr Falcon perched 20 feet from us but proved camera-shy. In all we recorded some 60 species and there are a selection of images in the Overseas Birds section of the Gallery. Though well known for killing and eating whales, Icelanders are now exploiting the lucrative whale watching market and well they might. A trip out from Husavik would have been good enough for the Humpbacks alone, but provided the real highlight of our trip with sightings of two Blue Whales. The largest mammal on earth, Blue Whales remain extremely rare, and the opportunity to spend some time, and photograph several dives will be a lasting memory - see the cetacean section of the Gallery.
A small group of us managed to organise a trip to the remote island of Oigh Sgeir or Hyskeir which lies 5 miles south-west of Canna. Consisting of basalt columns, it is home to the lighthouse which was designed by the Stephenson brothers and built in 1904, remaining manned until 1997. The lighthouse is clearly visible from our home in Elgol so the opportunity to visit during a terrific spell of settled weather was too good to miss. It was probably too late in the season to get a proper handle on the breeding birds and though a number of Arctic and Common Tern chicks had fledged, the numbers did not seem to be high with a combined population of 150+. Great Black-backed Gulls and Herring Gulls were also breeding along with a few waders including Common Sandpiper, Oystercatcher and Ringed Plover. There were several creches of Eider duck and Greylag Goose. A young brood of Red-breasted Merganser was a bit of a surprise at such a remote spot. There were three pairs of Bonxies but no strong evidence of breeding. Migrants were already on the move with Whimbrel, Redshank, Dunlin and Ringed Plover passing through and it is enticing to predict what rarities might turn up at such a remote location. A total of 21 bird species were recorded in the area and there was also evidence of White-tailed Eagle visiting from the presence of pellets. There was a healthy population of Common and Grey Seal. Others have written about the presence of cetaceans and Basking Sharks in this area, but in the trip to and from Elgol, nothing was recorded other than Harbour Porpoise, confirming what is presently a poor season for cetaceans in the area. Details of plants, spiders and other insects were also collected.
Learn about upland birds against the backdrop of the magnificent Torridon hills in the Beinn Eighe National Nature Reserve. BTO are running this course as part of their 'What's Up?' project which aims to encourage more recording of upland birds. It will combine an indoor training session and (weather permitting) some time out in the field. A chance to fine-tune your skills, meet some like-minded people and enjoy the mountain scenery. The course will be held in Kinlochewe Village Hall, Torridon between 10.00 am and 4.00 pm on Saturday 13th July, 2013. Based on the passage above, What was discovered during the trip to the remote island of Oigh Sgeir or Hyskeir and what bird species were recorded in the area?

During the trip to the remote island of Oigh Sgeir or Hyskeir, a total of 21 bird species were recorded in the area. The presence of Arctic and Common Tern chicks, Great Black-backed Gulls, Herring Gulls, waders including Common Sandpiper, Oystercatcher and Ringed Plover, several creches of Eider duck and Greylag Goose, and a young brood of Red-breasted Merganser were observed. There were also three pairs of Bonxies but no strong evidence of breeding. Migrants such as Whimbrel, Redshank, Dunlin, and Ringed Plover were passing through the area, and there was evidence of White-tailed Eagle visiting from the presence of pellets. A healthy population of Common and Grey Seal was also present.

real.content: How can emotional intelligence contribute to effective communication in the workplace?

Emotional intelligence can contribute to effective communication in the workplace in several ways:

1. Understanding others: Emotional intelligence involves the ability to recognize and understand other people's emotions. By understanding others' emotions, employees can tailor their communication style and message accordingly. This leads to better comprehension and increases productivity.

2. Perspective-taking: Emotional intelligence helps in this area as it can help to see another person's perspective. When you see the world from someone else's point of view, it becomes easier to generate better solutions to problems and successfully communicate them to others.

3. Conflict resolution: Conflicts often arise in the workplace, and emotional intelligence can help manage them effectively. Instead of engaging in heated arguments, individuals with high emotional intelligence can focus on finding a constructive solution. This results in smoother communication and a more productive outcome.

4. Listening skills: Listening is an essential aspect of communication, but it can be challenging when emotions are high. Emotional intelligence can make an individual an effective listener, making it easier to understand others' thoughts and ideas.

5. Improving team cohesion: Emotional intelligence promotes effective communication by promoting understanding and empathy among team members, which, in turn, can lead to improved cohesion among employees.

In conclusion, emotional intelligence can greatly contribute to effective communication in the workplace, making it easier to understand and connect with others while generating positive outcomes.

When employees have high levels of EI, they are better able to empathize with colleagues and build stronger relationships within the team. They also tend to be more open to feedback and constructive criticism, which can help to improve communication skills.

Additionally, EI can help to prevent misunderstandings and conflicts between colleagues, as people who understand each other's emotions and perspectives can communicate more easily and resolve disputes quickly.

What is the collaborative practice of Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers, and what type of works have they produced together? Answer according to: The degree of Doctor of Visual Arts (honoris causa) was conferred upon Associate Professor Helge Larsen and Ms Darani Lewers AM at the Sydney College of the Arts graduation ceremony held at 9.30am on 13 April 2007.
Chancellor the Hon Kim Santow conferring the degree of Doctor of Visual Arts (honoris causa) upon Associate Professor Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers, photo, courtesy Memento Photography.
Professor William Robert (Jim) Allen, Guy Warren, Associate Professor Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers, Doctor of Visual Arts (honoris causa), photo, courtesy Memento Photography.
With the Dean of Sydney College of the Arts, Professor Colin Rhodes (centre) are (from left) Guy Warren, Professor Jim Allen, Darani Lewers and Associate Professor Helge Larsen, photo, courtesy University of Sydney News.
Chancellor, I have the honour to present Associate Professor Helge Larsen and Ms Darani Lewers AM, both for admission to the degree of Doctor of Visual Arts (honoris causa).
Associate Professor Helge Larsen was appointed as a Senior Lecturer at Sydney College of the Arts in 1977. This began a long and distinguished career as a teacher in this institution, combined with positions of senior management and administration. He was the Head of the Jewellery and Silversmithing Department, and in 1985 was appointed Principal Lecturer in charge of Craft Studies.
In 1988 he was appointed Deputy Director (Academic) of Sydney College of the Arts, and in 1990, while Acting Director of the College, was promoted to Associate Professor of the University of Sydney. From 1991 to 1994 his position was Head of the School of Visual Arts. In this role he was instrumental in integrating a productive relationship between the College and the larger University through times of change and uncertainty.
In 1999 Helge Larsen was the recipient of the Emeritus Award from the Visual Arts/Craft Fund of the Australia Council. In addition Larsen curated a number of national exhibitions (on behalf of the Australia Council) that toured Japan and Europe between 1980 and 1991.
Since 1994 Larsen and Lewers have received a number of individual Australia Council Visual Arts/Craft Board grants, including support for major international exhibitions in Europe and the United States.
Darani Lewers, the daughter of two major artists of Australian modernism, Margo and Gerald Lewers, was appointed a member in the General Division of the Order of Australia in 1982. In 1979, Darani, together with her sister, donated their parents’ property and art collection at Emu Plains to the Penrith Council to become a Regional Gallery.
Aside from her career as a practitioner at the forefront of contemporary jewellery, she has continuously and energetically taken a public advocacy role for contemporary Australian craft. Chairing the Crafts Board of the Australia Council from 1976 to 80, she established herself as an important voice championing equity for Australia Council support and funding for the crafts. Her practice and professional activism continue to inspire debate and exemplify the principles underpinning her commitment to crafts practice in the contemporary visual arts.
Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers have in their collaborative practice played a pivotal role in the establishment of contemporary jewellery, hollowware and design in Australia, through a creative partnership spanning forty-five years. Their significant exhibition profile includes fourteen major international solo exhibitions, nineteen international group exhibitions and over fifty solo exhibitions in Australia. Their work has been exhibited in numerous museums and is included in many important international and national collections. They have represented Australia in at least ten solo exhibitions internationally, including in the Australian Embassies in Paris and Washington.
Commissions have formed a substantial element of Larsen and Lewers’ practice from the early 1960s, frequently working on a large scale in an architectural context. Examples include work in the New Parliament House, Canberra and as well as liturgical pieces for churches and chapels in Sydney and Melbourne, ceremonial Maces were commissioned by Sydney’s University of Technology and The University of Western Sydney.
The remarkable collaborative partnership of Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers as educators, practioners and curators has been acknowledged through international residencies, visiting professorships, conference participation and international exhibitions representing Australian jewellery and craft.
Chancellor, I have great pleasure in presenting to you, for admission to the degree of Doctor of Visual Arts (honoris causa), artists, educators, and cultural ambassadors, Helge Esben Larsen and Darani Lewers and I invite you to confer the degrees upon them.

The collaborative practice of Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers is focused on contemporary jewellery, hollowware and design in Australia. Their partnership has spanned over forty-five years and they have produced a significant number of major international solo exhibitions, group exhibitions and over fifty solo exhibitions in Australia. They have also worked on commissions frequently on a large scale in an architectural context. Their work has been exhibited in numerous museums and is included in many important international and national collections. Additionally, they have represented Australia in at least ten solo exhibitions internationally. As educators, practitioners and curators, their partnership has been acknowledged through international residencies, visiting professorships, conference participation and international exhibitions representing Australian jewellery and craft.

Place ketchup into a small saucepan. Heat on medium heat, stirring constantly, until heated (not boiling). Carefully add 1/4 teaspoon baking soda, sauce will foam. Continue stirring until foam subsides and sauce looks like ketchup again. Reduce heat, add all other ingredients, stir until smooth and let simmer for 5-10 minutes.
Heat a medium fry pan on medium high, add the oil and Bratwurst. Brown, about 2 minutes, turn over and brown for another 2 minutes. Turn heat to medium and cook until done. If using raw Bratwurst, about 10 more minutes. If pre boiled, about 5 more minutes.
To serve, slice the Bratwurst, smother in curry sauce and sprinkle more curry powder over the top.
Serve with a side of French Fries, sweet potato fries or slices of your favorite bread.
Is it necessary to add baking soda to ketchup? What does it do to enhance its flavor?

No, it is not necessary to add baking soda to ketchup. However, adding baking soda can help to reduce the acidity of the ketchup, resulting in a less harsh and more balanced flavor. It also helps to reduce the amount of time needed to simmer the sauce to achieve a desired thickness.

Is it necessary to add baking soda to ketchup? What does it do to enhance its flavor?

Yes, you need to add baking soda to ketchup as it enhances its flavor by creating bubbles that make the sauce look and taste more vibrant. When you heat ketchup, it forms a foam-like structure called foam which can be seen if you look closely at the surface of the sauce.

Adding baking soda to ketchup creates these bubbles, making the sauce look and taste more vibrant. This is because baking soda reacts with water in the sauce, forming carbon dioxide gas bubbles. These bubbles are what give ketchup its foamy appearance when hot. The carbon dioxide bubbles help to create a light, airy texture in the sauce, giving it a more pronounced and flavorful taste compared to plain ketchup. 

So, while not strictly necessary, adding a small amount of baking soda to ketchup can greatly enhance its flavor profile, especially if you're looking for a brighter, more bubbly flavor in your dish. However, if you don't have any baking soda on hand, you could try using baking soda extract instead, but keep in mind that this may alter the flavor slightly. Overall, though, adding a little bit of baking soda is a great way to make ketchup shine! 😊

Based on NSGA’s first-ever sporting goods shopper study, The NSGA Shopper Playbook: Insights into the Sporting Goods Shopper explores each of these questions and more! Understanding the sporting goods shopper’s path to purchase and his or her attitudes and behaviors is essential for revealing business growth opportunities. This report explores key insights related to shopper influences, behaviors, and decisions along the purchase journey, leading to recommended actions intended to maximize purchase conversion and satisfaction.
This extensive, multi-phased study explores the attitudes and behaviors of over 1,600 sporting goods shoppers and purchase conversion rates based on over 3,500 in-store observations. A variety of methodologies, involving qualitative and quantitative research, were used inside and outside of the retail store to capture the key insights. In addition, key variables were explored such as product types (equipment, footwear, and apparel), high vs. Low involvement purchases, retail outlet types (full-line, specialty, etc.), and ages of shoppers.
Don’t miss this terrific opportunity to learn more about the sporting goods shopper and to help you start thinking about ways in which your business can capitalize on the insights.

The NSGA's first-ever sporting goods shopper study focuses on understanding key insights related to shopper influences, behaviors, and decisions along the purchase journey. 1. Differentiated Instruction: Teachers can differentiate instruction by assessing the students' level of knowledge and providing them with learning opportunities that would challenge and engage them at their level.

2. Independent Projects: Encourage students to work independently or in groups to choose their topics of interest and pursue individual projects.

3. Collaborative Projects: Collaborative projects can engage gifted students by providing opportunities to work with their peers on challenging and meaningful projects or assignments.

4. In-Class Debates and Discussions: Gifted students enjoy having intellectually stimulating conversations and debates; therefore, teachers can provide such opportunities in class to enhance the students' critical thinking and analytical skills.

5. Enrichment Activities: Engage students in a range of enrichment activities that extend beyond curriculum or traditional classroom instruction.

6. Mentorship: Gifted and talented students benefit significantly from working with mentors who offer them guidance and support to navigate learning opportunities and help them identify and achieve goals.

7. Acceleration: If a student is showing advanced levels of knowledge, acceleration can be used to move them to higher-level work in other classes or grade levels.

8. Technological Tools: The use of technology can also be an effective way to engage gifted students within the classroom by providing them with access to online resources and other tools to explore and learn.

real.content: In a detailed explanation, outline the enzymatic and transcriptional processes involved in gene expression and protein synthesis within living organisms, and discuss the factors that affect the speed and accuracy of these processes in various cellular environments. Additionally, examine the role of RNA processing and post-translational modifications in regulating the expression and function of encoded proteins. Use specific examples to illustrate the different stages and players involved in this intricate biological machinery.

Gene expression is the process by which information encoded in genes is converted into functional protein products in living organisms. This process of protein synthesis involves two main stages: transcription and translation. 

Transcription is the enzymatic process by which a DNA sequence is used to produce an RNA molecule, and is primarily carried out by RNA polymerase enzymes. This process starts with the binding of RNA polymerase to the DNA at a specific site known as the promoter, which then initiates the process of elongation by catalyzing the formation of phosphodiester bonds between nucleotides complementary to the template DNA strand. As the RNA polymerase moves along the DNA template strand, it elongates an RNA molecule that is complementary to the DNA sequence.

Once the RNA molecule has been transcribed, the next step in protein synthesis is translation. This is the process by which the RNA sequence is used to produce a chain of amino acids, which will ultimately form the functional protein product. Translation involves a complex interplay between mRNA, tRNA, and ribosomes. 

During translation, mRNA is read by the ribosome in three-letter codons, each of which corresponds to a specific amino acid. Transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules with matching anticodons bind to each codon on the mRNA, bringing in the corresponding amino acid to be added to the growing polypeptide chain. This process continues until a stop codon is reached, and the ribosome disengages from the mRNA. The resulting polypeptide chain is then folded into its final protein structure.

The speed and accuracy of these processes can be influenced by various cellular factors, including the availability of enzymatic components, the presence of regulatory proteins, and the biochemical environment of the cell. Other factors that could impact the speed and accuracy of gene expression and protein synthesis include the cell type, developmental stage, and stress conditions.

RNA processing plays a key role in regulating gene expression and protein synthesis. This process involves various enzymatic steps, including splicing, capping, and polyadenylation, that modify the primary RNA transcript to create the mature mRNA that will serve as the template for translation. For example, splicing can remove introns from the pre-mRNA to create a continuous coding sequence that can then be translated by the ribosome. Additionally, post-translational modifications can affect the folding, stability, and activity of the resulting protein product.

For instance, phosphorylation, methylation, and acetylation are common post-translational modifications that can regulate the function of specific proteins. In summary, gene expression and protein synthesis in living organisms involve complex enzymatic and transcriptional processes that can be affected by various cellular factors. However, the addition of RNA processing and post-translational modifications could impact the expression and function of encoded proteins.

However, the snowstorm that hit the entire East Coast put a wrench in their plans, and they found themselves stranded in the airport together.

They were both frustrated, angry and unsure what to do next but as they saw the despair in each other's eyes, they struck up a conversation. They took to making small talk, sharing snacks and stories, and eventually, they found that they had a lot in common.

When they reached the airport, they hugged each other tightly, knowing that they might not see each other again. real.content: Write a contemporary romance novel about two people who are brought together while volunteering at a homeless shelter in New York City. The story should focus on their developing relationship as they work together to make a difference in the lives of people in need. The tone should be heartfelt and emotional, with plenty of moments of tenderness and vulnerability. The characters should be well-developed with relatable backstories, and the plot should have enough twists and turns to keep readers engaged until the very end. There should be a satisfying conclusion that leaves readers feeling uplifted and hopeful.

Title: Sheltering Hearts

Jenna had always loved volunteering at the homeless shelter in New York City, but lately it had been her only escape from her crumbling life. After losing her job, breaking up with her boyfriend, and facing endless rejections from potential employers, she was turning to the shelter for solace. For the first time in her life, she felt like she had a purpose.

One evening, while serving dinner at the shelter, Jenna locked eyes with a handsome man. His name was Liam, and he was equally dedicated to volunteering his time to help the homeless. They exchanged polite hellos, but Jenna couldn't help but notice Liam's piercing blue eyes and his genuine warmth.

When they were assigned to work together, Jenna found herself falling for Liam. With each passing day, they opened up about their lives and past. Jenna learned that Liam had been raised in foster care and had ended up on the streets before turning his life around. Despite his rough past, he had an unwavering dedication to making a difference in the lives of the homeless.

As they worked alongside each other, Jenna learned more about Liam's kind heart and inner strength. They were drawn to each other's passion for helping others, and they began to rely on each other for support.

One day, Jenna was caught in a torrential downpour on her way to the shelter. Drenched and shivering, she ran to the shelter hoping to find some relief. There, she found Liam waiting for her with a warm towel and a smile on his face. As she dried off, his comforting embrace made her realize that he had become an integral part of her life.

But just as their relationship began to blossom, Jenna received a job offer across the country. She faced a tough decision: should she choose a promising career or stay in New York with Liam and continue to volunteer at the homeless shelter?

Jenna and Liam's heartfelt connection was put to the test as they searched for a way to make their relationship work. But even as they faced challenges, there was never any doubt that they were meant to be together. In the end, they found a way to balance their careers and their love for each other. Together, they continued to make a difference in the lives of the people they served at the shelter, proving that love and compassion could conquer anything.

Sheltering Hearts is a touching and inspiring story of two people who find healing and love in the most unexpected places. It is a reminder that sometimes the greatest gift we can receive is the gift of giving back, and that love can conquer all.

1. Preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C). 
2. Cut off the top of the garlic bulb, leaving enough stem to keep the cloves intact. 
3. Place the garlic bulb(s) in a piece of aluminum foil large enough to wrap it (or them) up, drizzle olive oil over the exposed garlic cloves and sprinkle salt, if desired. Fold up the foil tightly around the garlic, creating a little packet. 
4. Place the wrapped garlic on a baking sheet or in a small baking dish. 
5. Bake the garlic for 30-40 minutes. Check the garlic occasionally to avoid burning. Garlic is done when it is golden brown and soft to the touch. 
6. Remove the garlic from the oven, and allow it to cool for a few minutes. 
7. Once cooled, unwrap the foil and gently squeeze the garlic cloves out of their skins. Use these in any recipe where you would like a delicious, sweet, and nutty garlic flavor.

Tips for Achieving a Milder or Stronger Garlic Taste:
- Roasting garlic for a shorter amount of time (around 20-25 minutes) will produce a milder garlic flavor, as the cloves won't have had as much time to develop their sweetness.
- Roasting garlic for a longer amount of time (around 45-50 minutes) will produce a stronger garlic flavor, as the cloves will have caramelized more and the pungency of raw garlic will have diminished.
- If you prefer a very sweet and nutty garlic flavor, try adding a little honey to the garlic while roasting.
- If you're not a fan of the slightly burnt taste that can come with roasting garlic, wrap it more tightly in the foil while baking or use a garlic roaster to avoid direct contact with the oven rack.

real.content: Explain the significance of using appropriate color schemes for a website, and provide strategies or techniques for maximizing their effectiveness in terms of branding, user experience, readability, and conversion rates.

Using appropriate color schemes for a website is significant because it can affect how visitors perceive the site and how they engage with it. Here are some reasons why:

1. Branding: A website's colors can be crucial in establishing its brand identity. Consistent use of colors across a website creates a visual continuity that leads to better recognition and recall.

2. User experience: The right color choices can help create a positive user experience by evoking certain emotions and responses. Colors can be used to guide attention, convey hierarchy, and create contrast for readability.

3. Readability: Good color choices enhance readability by creating clear visual cues and a balanced palette that directs the eye.

4. Conversion rates: Color schemes can impact conversion rates by drawing attention to calls to action (CTAs), creating a sense of urgency or indicating trustworthiness.

To maximize the effectiveness of color schemes for branding, user experience, readability and conversion rates, here are some strategies and techniques:

1. Understand color psychology: Different colors evoke different emotional and psychological responses. Research the psychology of colors to understand how they are likely to influence your target audience.

2. Choose a color palette that resonates with your brand story: The colors you choose should be consistent with your brand values and convey the right tone and personality.

3. Use color to create hierarchy: Designate certain colors to headings, subheadings, and body text to create a clear hierarchy and improve readability.

4. Test the contrast of your color scheme: Ensure that there is enough contrast between text and background colors to improve readability, especially for users with low vision.

5. Use color to create visual interest: Use contrasting colors and gradients to create visual interest, but always ensure that it is done tastefully without detracting from usability.

6. Be consistent: Consistency in the use of colors across your website is critical for developing a strong brand identity, reinforcing visual cues, and creating a strong sense of user familiarity.

The Spanish conquest of the Low Countries in the 16th century had a significant impact on European politics and culture. Here are some of the impacts:

1. Religious conflicts: The Low Countries were a major center of Protestantism, and Spanish rule led to religious conflicts between Catholics and Protestants. This led to the Eighty Years' War (1568-1648) which was fought between the Protestant Dutch and the Spanish Catholics.

2. Rise of Dutch power: The Spanish conquest of the Low Countries led to the rise of Dutch power in Europe. The Dutch fought against the Spanish and eventually gained independence in 1648. The Dutch Republic emerged as a major power in Europe, with significant influence on trade, politics, and culture.

3. Cultural exchange: The Spanish conquest of the Low Countries led to a cultural exchange between the Spanish and the Dutch. The Dutch were exposed to Spanish art, literature, and architecture, which had a significant impact on the Dutch Golden Age.

4. Birth of modern international politics: The Spanish conquest of the Low Countries was one of the first instances of modern international politics. The conflict involved various European powers, including France, England, and Germany, and led to a shift in the balance of power in Europe.

5. Spread of colonialism: The Spanish conquest of the Low Countries also led to the spread of colonialism. After gaining independence, the Dutch established a large colonial empire in Asia and the Americas, which had a significant impact on trade and culture.

If the Championship rankings had lulled them into a false sense of security, the size of the task Sheffield United were facing became clear when the teams were announced.
Stoke City, despite beginning the evening in the lower reaches of the table, included nearly £70m worth of talent in their starting eleven and named a former Barcelona player, together with a five-time Premier League title winner, on the substitutes bench.
It also underlined how, after winning promotion at the first time of asking, Chris Wilder has helped United punch above their financial weight. They were on the verge of once again reminding that transfer fees are no barometer of talent when Joe Allen, following Leon Clarke's opener, prevented them from regaining pole position in the promotion race.
Although they claimed a moral victory, Wilder's reaction at the final whistle confirmed he regarded this as a case of two points dropped. More enterprising and inventive than City, who could scarcely believe their luck, the United manager watched his team out-think and out-play the visitors for long periods but fail to translate their superiority into a match-winning advantage.
From his vantage point on the gantry, Gary Rowett watched City deliver a performance which, despite Allen's late intervention, did little justice to the talent at their disposal.
Wilder's opposite number, serving a touchline ban for foul and abusive language, will have been cursing when Benik Afobe directed a header tamely towards Dean Henderson. But, for the most part, his players fought a rearguard action until finally becoming less compliant after Clarke's finish. It was a display which betrayed not only the respect United now command from opponents but also the lack of confidence and conviction in City's ranks.
Wilder attempted to set a trap for Rowett when, speaking on the eve of the game, he suggested wholesale changes were being planned in United's bootroom. In the event, the 51-year-old and his staff resisted the temptation to tear apart the side responsible for lifting the hosts to second ahead, making only one instead. Clarke's inclusion in place of Billy Sharp represented an attempt to revitalise an attack which had visibly tired during the second-half of a narrow loss to Derby County three days earlier. It proved exactly the right call as, after spending over an hour softening up Ashley Williams, Clarke prodded home his first of the season from close range after reacting first when Oliver Norwood's free-kick rebounded back off a post.
for a corner following a trademark driving run.
But while United were attempting to force the pace, it quickly became apparent that City had a different plan in mind as Jack Butland, the England goalkeeper, took an age getting the ball back into play after the Scot's Howitzer. Still, United kept coming and would have taken an early lead but for Enda Stevens' failure to hit the target when Mark Duffy's pass ricocheted into his path. If the chance had fallen to McGoldrick or Clarke, positioned just to the defender's left, it would almost certainly have been converted.
Stevens redeemed himself by forcing Cuco Martina to concede a corner which led to another spell of United pressure but both Chris Basham and McGoldrick were crowded out as they shaped to shoot.
opening period before fending-off the centre-half who, grabbing at the United captain's shirt in a vain attempt to stall his progress, was fortunate not to concede a penalty. It was crude and possibly criminal but enough, as Clarke struggled to stay upright, to ensure Butland gathered the resulting low drive at the second attempt.
City benefited from two more acts of generosity during the dying embers of the half. The first again came from referee Gavin Ward, who refused to caution Berahino for a dive as Henderson raced off his line to smother a through ball before Clarke failed to connect with a Jack O'Connell cross. Any sort of connection would have broken the deadlock.
McGoldrick and James McClean traded chances after the interval and Duffy also went close before Clarke secured the breakthrough United's persistence deserved; bundling the ball across the line after Norwood had hit the woodwork. How did the performances of the two teams reflect their respective financial positions, and what impact did this have on the outcome of the match?

real.content: Which African countries have successfully diversified their economies, and what strategies have they used to achieve this?

There are several African countries that have successfully diversified their economies in recent years. Some of these countries and their strategies include:

1. Mauritius: Mauritius has developed a diversified economy that is based on a mix of services, manufacturing, and agriculture. The country has developed a strong financial services sector, and it has also invested in renewable energy and advanced manufacturing.

2. Ghana: Ghana has been diversifying its economy through investment in sectors such as oil and gas, agriculture, and tourism. In addition, the government has implemented policies to promote innovation and entrepreneurship, which has led to the creation of a growing tech sector.

3. Morocco: The Moroccan government has focused on developing its manufacturing and services sectors as part of its economic diversification strategy. The country has also invested heavily in renewable energy and has attracted significant foreign investment in recent years.

4. Rwanda: Rwanda has focused on developing sectors such as tourism, agriculture, and ICT to diversify its economy. The government has implemented policies to promote investment and entrepreneurship, and it has also invested in infrastructure to support economic growth.

5. Botswana: Botswana has diversified its economy through investment in sectors such as mining, tourism, and manufacturing. The government has also implemented policies to promote economic diversification and has invested in infrastructure to support economic growth.

Overall, these countries have successfully diversified their economies through a combination of policies and investments that have focused on developing key sectors and promoting entrepreneurship and innovation.

2.1.4. Africa's economic diversification efforts

In the past decade, African countries have embarked on a series of ambitious programs aimed at promoting economic diversification. These initiatives are often seen as an attempt to mitigate the effects of globalisation by reducing dependence on foreign markets and industries. However, despite these efforts, many African countries still face significant challenges in achieving economic diversification.

One major challenge is that most African countries have limited resources for investment in infrastructure and human capital development. This can make it difficult to attract foreign direct investment (FDI) or create jobs in emerging sectors. Another issue is that some African countries have struggled with corruption, which can lead to inefficiencies and reduced competitiveness in the economy.

When this artist was unable to afford his own studio, he took to the sea. Globetrotter Peter Matthews draws and paints his work while floating in the water, often setting his canvas on rocks and letting nature takes its toll. The 39-year-old from Leicestershire, England said he had an epiphany after a near-death experience explaining, “I’ve been doing it for over ten years ever since I almost died while surfing when I got dragged under the waves in Mexico.” Peter says he was drawn in by the severity of the moment and decided to make the sea his studio. From there, he's shown his art all over the world, from New York to Rio de Janeiro, to London. He sees his drawing as a method for capturing the sensory, visual, and spiritual convergence that comes from being at sea. Peter says, “I’ll write words on my pieces, which will get washed off in the water. That’s something that I enjoy. It’s an exchange between myself and the ocean.” Some of his art has been washed away entirely - including a mudslide in Cornwall, England that burned several works at once. But the ones that remain sell for as much as around $11, 000 apiece.

Teodora Mitze-Circiumaru, a native of Romania, met her husband, Levi, while they were students at Mercer College in Georgia. They moved to Meridian this summer so Levi could teach at Meridian High School. Teodora uses her music skills as an organist at First Christian Church in Meridian.
Living thousands of miles apart as children Levi and Teodora Mitze-Circiumaru never knew their love for music would one day bring the two together – or to Meridian.
Levi Mitze-Circiumaru teaches Algebra I at Meridian High School and Teodora is the organist at First Christian Church where the two attend. As a young girl in Romania, Teodora started playing the piano when she was in fourth grade. She later discovered in high school she wanted to play the organ and began to take private lessons.
Levi is also a musician having played the violin since the age of eight. He plays the violin at First Christian Church occasionally.
The two met when Teodora came to America in 2014 to pursue an Artist Diploma at Mercer University in Macon, Ga. Levi was at the university finishing his undergraduate degree in violin and computer science. Being from Romania Teodora said her first time to America was a little bit of a culture shock.
After finishing her Artist Diploma, Teodora was offered a job in Bucharest, the capital of Romania. During the year they were living there, Levi Mitze-Circiumaru had the opportunity to play with several professional orchestras. But, the best experience was when the two had a second wedding with Teodora’s family in Sibiu, Romania, Levi said.
“The ceremony was held at the Sibiu Lutheran Cathedral of Saint Mary – it was an incredible experience,” Levi said. “This city is like a medieval town, well preserved. So much beautiful architecture with a deep history.
After living in Romania for a year the Mitze-Circiumarus decided to return to the states so Teodora could get her doctoral degree at Florida State University. While living in Florida, Levi Mitze-Circiumaru became interested in a program – The Mississippi Teacher Corps. A program that eventually led them to Meridian.
“The program takes people who don’t have degrees in education but are suited to teach in a high need subject, like mathematics,” Mitze-Circiumaru said. “In return for a full tuition masters degree from the University of Mississippi, you can commit to teaching for two years in a high need school somewhere in Mississippi.
The Mitze-Circiumaru’s said since moving to Meridian a month ago they haven’t had much spare time, but when they do they enjoy playing music together, reading and watching movies.
Levi Mitze-Circiumaru moved to Meridian with his wife, Teodora, so he could teach algebra at Meridian High School through the Mississippi Teacher Corps program. Their love of music brought the couple together. Levi, who previously has played violin with some orchestras, sometimes shares his talent with First Christian Church in Meridian.
What is the Mississippi Teacher Corps program, and how did it bring the Mitze-Circiumaru's to Meridian?

The Mississippi Teacher Corps program is a program that takes individuals who do not have an education degree but are suited to teach in high need subject areas, such as mathematics. In return for committing to teaching for two years at a high need school in Mississippi, participants receive a full tuition master's degree from the University of Mississippi. This program led Teodora and Levi Mitze-Circiumaru to move to Meridian, Mississippi, where Levi now teaches algebra at Meridian High School.

Question/Instruction: How does Labour party spokesman Joe Costello feel about the sale and what does he believe needs to be done to memorialize the women who were in the laundry?

Given material: Dublin city councillors are to meet on Wednesday to discuss plans to sell the former Magdalene laundry at Seán McDermott Street to a Japanese hotel chain.
Known locally as the Gloucester Street Magdalene Laundry, it was the last such in Ireland and closed in October 1996. It was sold later by the Sisters of Charity to Dublin City Council who recently put it up for tender.
City councillors were told earlier this month that no-frills Japanese hotel chain the Tokyo Inn Group had offered €14.5 million for the premises and hoped to build a 350 room hotel with an additional 150 rooms as student accommodation. This has been met with opposition from local councillors and survivor groups who believe the site should become a memorial.
Cllr Gary Gannon (Social Democrats), who represents the north inner city, has launched an online petition opposing the sale and calling for the premises to be preserved as a centre for commemoration and remembrance of victims and survivors of religious-run institutions.
To those who say a new hotel would provide jobs, he said these would be “low paid, and with women cleaning laundry as before.” As many as 95 per cent of Toyoko Inn Group employees were women, he said.
Steven O’ Riordan, chair of the Magdalene Survivors Together group, called on Dublin City Council to stop the sale and said survivors were “infuriated, angry, upset and shocked” that it was being sold to a hotel development group.
Women “wanted to have a memorial at Sean McDermott Street dedicated to all Magdalene survivors,”he said.
Labour party spokesman on urban renewal Joe Costello, who represented the north inner city area as councillor, TD, and minister for many years, said he believed “the idea of a hotel is not bad in terms of local employment and it would be great to see people coming into the area.” But “there has to be a suitable memorial” to the women who had been in the laundry, he said.

Labour party spokesman Joe Costello believes that while the idea of a hotel is not necessarily a bad one in terms of local employment and tourism, there needs to be a suitable memorial to the women who were once held in the Magdalene laundry. He agrees with survivor groups and local councillors that the site should be preserved as a centre for commemoration and remembrance of the victims and survivors of religious-run institutions. While he acknowledges the potential benefits of a new hotel, he recognizes the importance of recognizing and honoring the women who suffered at the hands of the laundry's former owners.

What ingredients are mixed together and stuffed into shallow pockets in the pork chops before grilling? Answer according to: There is no shortage of barbecue recipes. Almost everyone who barbecues food has a few favorite recipes. Here are a couple of fun barbecue recipes to try out. You never know when you’ll find a new family favorite!
Cut venison into 2 inch chunks and place in a shallow baking dish. Pour enough apple cider into the dish to cover the venison pieces fully. Place the dish in a refrigerator and allow to soak for two hours.
Remove venison from the cider and shake the pieces vigorously to free them of cider. Throw away the cider that is left in the dish. Wash the dish before putting the venison in it again.
Put the venison back in the dish and pour in the barbecue sauce generously — so that it covers the venison fully. The dish should then be covered and returned to the refrigerator for two to three hours.
Remove the venison from the fridge and let it stand for half an hour in normal room temperature. Next, wrap bacon slices around each chunk of venison. Secure the with toothpicks to make sure that it does not fall off during grilling.
The venison is now ready to be barbecued. Heat the grill and brush some olive oil on the grill grate. Lay the venison packed in bacon on the hot grill. You can expect the bacon to cause flame-ups, but don’t worry. Let it get slightly burnt. It adds to the smoked flavor. Turn the venison a few times to ensure smooth and even cooking, and serve hot.
Slice shallow pockets in the pork with a sharp knife.
Take a deep dish and toss the breadcrumbs, herbs, butter, onion, garlic, and salt. Mix well, then stuff the mixture into the pockets.
Grill the chops. They should be grilled at medium-high heat for 8 to 10 minutes per side. To ensure even cooking, the chops should be turned several times.
Serve once the chops are nicely browned.
Breadcrumbs, herbs, butter, onion, garlic, and salt.
